content.text: Explain briefly, with the help of a diagram, how you would use a metre rule and set square to measure the length \(d\) of a pendulum as accurately as possible
Diagram:
Record the time \(t_1\) shown in Fig. 1.3
Fig. 1.3
Calculate the period \(T_{1}\) of the pendulum. The period is the time for one complete oscillation
The student adjusts the pendulum so that \(d = 50.0 \text{cm}\). She displaces the bob slightly and releases it so that it swings. Fig. 1.2 shows one complete oscillation of the pendulum
She measures the time \(t_1\) for 20 complete oscillations

parts.label: (c)

content.text: The student adjusts the pendulum until the distance \(d\) is \(100.0 \text{cm}\)
She repeats the procedure and records the time \(t_2\) for 20 oscillations and the period \(T_2\)
She measures the mass \(m_{\mathrm{A}}\) of the pendulum bob. The reading on the balance is shown in Fig. 1.4
Record mass \(m_{\mathrm{A}}\) of the pendulum bob to the nearest gram
The student repeats the procedure using a pendulum bob of mass \(m_{\mathrm{B}}\)

content.text: She obtains these results:

content.text: Using the results \(T_{1}\) , \(T_{2}\) , \(T_{3}\) and \(T_{4}\), for the period of each of the pendulums, tick \((\checkmark)\) the response that matches your results within the limits of experimental accuracy
the period \(T\) is affected by \(d\) only
the period \(T\) is affected by both \(d\) and \(m\)
the period \(T\) is affected by \(m\) only
the period \(T\) is not affected by \(d\) or \(m\)
Justify your answer to (d)(i) by reference to the results
Suggest briefly how you would measure the size of an oscillation. You may draw a diagram
State one variable that you would keep constant during this part of the investigation
The student now investigates the effect of the size of the oscillations on the period of the pendulum
A student investigates the period of a pendulum. Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2 show the apparatus she uses
Fig. 1.1
Fig. 1.2
路 The student places the sliding contact C on the resistance wire at a distance \(l = 10.0 \text{cm}\) from B
路 Record, in the first row of Table 2.1, the potential difference \(V\) across the length \(l = 10.0 \text{cm}\) of resistance wire, as shown on the voltmeter in Fig. 2.2
Fig. 2.2 Fig. 2.3
路 Record, in the first row of Table 2.1, the current \(I\) in the circuit as shown in Fig. 2.3
路 Complete the column headings in Table 2.1
The student repeats the procedure using \(l = 30.0 \text{cm}\), \(50.0 \text{cm}\), \(70.0 \text{cm}\) and \(90.0 \text{cm}\). The readings are shown in Table 2.1
Plot a graph of \(V / V\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(l / \text{cm}\) (\(x\)-axis). Start both axes at the origin (0,0)
Write a conclusion about the value of the current \(I\) in the circuit as the position of the sliding contact C is changed
Justify your conclusion by reference to your results
Using the graph, determine the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{L}}\) when the length \(l = 60.0 \text{cm}\)
Show clearly on the graph how you obtained your result
A student determines the resistance of a resistance wire
Fig. 2.1 shows the circuit he uses
The thermometer in Fig. 3.2 shows the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{S}}\) at the beginning of the experiment. Record \(\theta_{\mathrm{S}}\)
\(\theta_{\mathrm{S}} =\)   .........  \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)
Calculate the rise in temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the sand using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} = (\theta_{\mathrm{M}} - \theta_{\mathrm{S}})\)
\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\)   .........  \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)
Explain briefly what the student does after pouring the hot water into the sand and before taking the temperature, in order to obtain a reliable value for \(\theta_{\mathrm{M}}\)
Calculate the fall in temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}}\) of the hot water using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}} = (\theta_{\mathrm{H}} - \theta_{\mathrm{M}})\)
\(\theta_{\mathrm{F}} =\)   .........  \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)
Calculate the ratio \(S\) using the equation \(S = \frac{\theta_{\mathrm{R}}}{\theta_{\mathrm{F}}}\). Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment
The student is supplied with hot water at a temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\). She records the temperature of the hot water
\(\theta_{\mathrm{H}} =\)
She pours \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into a beaker that contains sand. Initially, the sand is at room temperature
She measures the highest temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{M}}\) of the mixture
\(\theta_{\mathrm{M}} =\)

The student pours \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water into a clean beaker that contains \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of water at room temperature. She records the highest temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{M}}\) of the mixture
\(\theta_{\mathrm{M}} =\)

Calculate the rise in temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the cold water using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} = (\theta_{\mathrm{M}} - \theta_{\mathrm{S}})\). Use the value of room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{S}}\) recorded in **(a)**
\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\)
Calculate the fall in temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}}\) of the hot water using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}} = (\theta_{\mathrm{H}} - \theta_{\mathrm{M}})\)
\(\theta_{\mathrm{F}} =\)
Calculate the ratio \(W\) using the equation \(W = \frac{\theta_{\mathrm{R}}}{\theta_{\mathrm{F}}}\)
The student studies the thermal properties of sand and water. She predicts that \(S\) should be equal to \(6 \times W\)
State whether the results support the prediction. Justify your answer by reference to the readings
Suggest two temperatures that it would be sensible to keep constant when carrying out the experiments

The student measures the volume of the dry sand using a measuring cylinder before carrying out the experiment. Tick \((\checkmark)\) the boxes that show the precautions that she should take in order to obtain an accurate reading
Take the reading at the bottom of the meniscus
Tap the measuring cylinder to make sure the top of the sand is horizontal
View the scale of the measuring cylinder at right angles
A student investigates some thermal properties of sand and water
Fig. 3.1 shows the apparatus
A student investigates the bending of \(1 \text{m}\) length strips of different materials. She compares how far they bend when loaded at one end
Plan an experiment to investigate how the material from which the strips are made affects the bending of the strips when loaded at one end
The following apparatus is available to the student:
strips of wood, plastic, steel and aluminium, each of length \(1 \text{m}\)
a set of slotted masses
a metre rule
a G-clamp (used to hold the strips to the laboratory bench)
Other apparatus normally available in a school laboratory can also be used
In your plan, you should:
draw a diagram to show the arrangement of the apparatus
explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation, including the measurements you would take
state the key variables to be kept constant
draw a suitable table, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)
explain how you would use the results to reach a conclusion
